Pyridine selective hydrogenation to piperidine is an important alternative to chemical synthesis. The commercial pyridine hydrogenation technologies taking Pt/Pd/Rh supported on carbon material as catalysts suffer from difficult molding and poor mechanical properties, resulting in their inability to be applied to continuous catalytic hydrogenation process. Here, Ti modified Pt-supported Al2O3 catalyst used in continuous hydrogenation process was synthesized via a one-pot hydrothermal method. Using a variety of complementary characterization methods, we identified the existence forms of Pt and Ti species in the catalyst. The results revealed that Ti modification decreased the density of strong Lewis acid sites on the catalysts, resulting in a decrease in Pt dispersion. Conversely, the introduction of Ti atoms significantly enhanced the reducibility of Pt species. This can be attributed to the formation of Ti3 + species, whose presence effectively facilitated the reduction of higher-valent Pt species (Pt2+ and Pt4+) to Pt0. The Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst with 7.5 wt% TiO2-containing achieved up to 87.8 % conversion of pyridine and 92.4 % selectivity of target product piperidine at 160 °C, 4.0 MPa, 300 H2/oil (v/v), and 6 h−1 LHSV in the fixed-bed continuous hydrogenation process, an improvement of 7.5 % and 9.9 % respectively, compared to Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. This optimal performance can be attributed to the balanced state of the active metal dispersion and reducibility at this specific Ti loading, where the synergy between these two factors maximized the active metal utilization ratio, thus leading to the catalyst being able to maximize its catalytic efficiency. Keywords Platinum TiO2-Al2O3 Pyridine Hydrogenation One-pot method Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Piperidine and its derivatives are pivotal compounds in the chemical industry, extensively utilized in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and organic synthesis, underscoring the demand for efficient and sustainable synthesis methods [1–3]. Currently, piperidines are mainly produced by intermittent selective hydrogenation of pyridines on batch reactors [4–7], which is difficult to meet the growing market demand for piperidines and exhibits high production costs. Substituting the traditional batch-reaction process with a continuous-reaction process holds great practical significance as the continuous-reaction process offers cost-effectiveness, high product stability, and is well-suited for large-scale production. Notably, there is currently no industrial catalyst specifically designed for the continuous hydrogenation of pyridine in fixed-bed or similar continuous units. This critical gap stems from the limitations of existing catalyst systems: the currently available catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of pyridine to piperidine are predominantly those in which precious metals like Pt, Pd, and Rh are supported on carbon materials [8,9]. For instance, Zhang et al. [10] fabricated a porous carbon - anchored Pd nanoparticle catalyst via a straightforward wet - impregnation method. This catalyst featured a large surface area and high nitrogen doping and was applied to the selective hydrogenation of quinoline, demonstrating excellent activity and selectivity. Nevertheless, the hydrogenation catalyst supported on carbon materials suffers from poor mechanical properties and stability, particularly in nanostructured forms optimized for catalysis, leading to fragmentation under high pressure. Additionally, the weak interaction between the active metal and carbon support accelerates active metal sintering and leaching under harsh hydrogenation conditions [11,12]. As a result, it is challenging to be employed in a fixed-bed continuous hydrogenation unit, which severely impedes the continuous production of piperidine compounds. Thus, there is an urgent need to develop a pyridine selective hydrogenation catalyst that combines activity, selectivity, and stability. To surmount the issue of inadequate catalyst stability attributed to the carbon support, researchers have proposed the concept of using various oxides with robust mechanical strength and stability (such as Al2O3, SiO2, and CeO2) as catalyst support materials [13–16]. Given that the dispersion state, crystal configuration, and electronic structure of active metals are intricately associated with the structure and surface properties of support materials, and the structure and surface properties of conventional oxide supports are relatively simplistic, it is arduous to accomplish the precise regulation of the properties of active metals. Consequently, the central problem in the research of high-performance pyridine hydrogenation catalysts lies in how to achieve the directional control of the crystal configuration and electronic structure of active metals on high-stability oxide supports. Al2O3 is extensively utilized as the support of hydrogenation catalysts in the fixed-bed industrial setting. This is owing to its superior mechanical strength, high stability, tunable pore structure, controllable acidity and low cost [17–19]. However, the surface properties of Al2O3 are relatively single, which makes it difficult to control the structure of active metals. Therefore, it is also hard for active metals to achieve both good dispersion and reducibility on the surface of Al2O3. Doping heteroatoms such as Cu, In, P, Ce, Ti, represents one of the primary approaches to modulate the structure and surface properties of active metals [20–24]. Among these, the Ti atom is particularly favored due to its diverse coordination states and the significant difference in electronegativity compared to the Al atom. Nguyen et al. [25] explored the impacts of varying TiO2 contents on the morphology and catalytic activity of the active phase in the CoMo/TiO2-Al2O3 hydrogenation catalyst. They discovered that TiO2 can facilitate the reduction, formation, and stacking of CoMoS active tablets by modifying the properties of Al2O3, thereby enhancing the hydrogenation activity of the catalyst. In our previous research [26,27], we synthesized a series of Al2O3 supports with different TiO2 contents using diverse methods, including in-situ synthesis, ion exchange, and mechanical mixing. And investigated the effects of the surface properties of these supports on the structure of NiW active metals and the hydrotreating activity of the corresponding catalysts for nitrides, and achieved the directional control of the active metal structure. However, there is virtually no literature reporting the mechanism by which in-situ Ti modification influences the surface properties and active metal structure of Pt/Al2O3 catalysts, let alone its application in the continuous selective hydrogenation of pyridine. Thus, we synthesized a series of Ti-modified Pt/Al2O3 catalysts with varying Ti contents via a one-pot in-situ method and applied them to the continuous selective hydrogenation of pyridine. The surface properties and structural characteristics of the catalysts and active metal were characterized using advanced techniques, such as FTIR, XPS, IGA, HAADF-STEM, CO pulse chemisorption and DFT calculation. The catalytic performance was evaluated in terms of activity, selectivity, and stability under continuous flow conditions. This work contributes to the ongoing efforts in designing advanced catalytic systems for industrial applications, emphasizing the importance of catalyst design and synthesis in achieving green and sustainable chemical processes. The findings are expected to contribute to the development of sustainable industrial processes for N-heterocycle functionalization, bridging critical gaps in heterogeneous catalysis research. 2 Experimental The Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared using a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method. The physicochemical properties of the catalysts were characterized by various means, including inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), nitrogen adsorption-desorption method, H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), scanning electron microscope (SEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), pyridine adsorbed Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR), Intelligent Gravimetric Analyzer (IGA), high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and CO pulse chemisorption. The surface charge distribution and interaction force with oxidic active metal of the Al2O3 support before and after Ti doping were calculated using density functional theory (DFT) as implemented in VASP package. Finally, pyridine hydrogenation was performed on a fixed-bed microreactor taking the mixture of pyridine and cyclohexane with the mass ratio of 1/19 as feed. For details, see the Supporting Information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Properties of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts The oxidic Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts with different content of TiO2 were prepared using a one-pot hydrothermal synthesis method. After reduction at 550 °C in the flow of a H2-Ar mixture, the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 were obtained. The exact TiO2 contents and Pt loadings were determined by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES), as shown in Table 1. The crystalline structures of the synthesized Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD). The XRD profiles ( Fig. 1a) show only the diffractions of Al2O3 and weak diffractions of TiO2, and the diffraction peaks of TiO2 are gradually obvious with the increase of TiO2 content. No diffraction peaks associated with neither Pt nor PtOx phase was detected, indicating that the Pt species are highly dispersed over the support or Pt particle size is too small to be detected by XRD[28]. The molecular structures of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts before and after reduction were confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), and the FTIR spectra are shown in Fig. 1b. The broad IR band at wavenumber of 400–1300 cm−1 is associated with the Al-O vibrations, and the bands at 1620 cm−1 and 2700–3750 cm−1 are considered to the generated by the hydroxyl groups or the absorbed water on the surface of the catalysts[29]. The results reveal that all the catalysts do not exhibit the absorption band attributed to Ti-O-Ti bond (495 cm−1), suggesting that Ti species were well dispersed in the catalysts using the one-pot method. In addition, any peaks characteristic to Pt–O bond has not been observed which may be due to the low concentration of the oxide, and this result is consistent with XRD results. It is worth noting that the oxidic catalysts exhibit two obvious absorption bands at wavenumbers of 1398 and 1528 cm−1, corresponding to the “free” (noncoordinated to any metal atoms) nitrate-ions and the v(NO)s respectively[30,31]. After H2 reduction, these two bands disappeared, indicating that the concentration of nitrate ions remaining on the catalyst surface was effectively reduced by this reduction method, which has a positive effect on reducing the content of Brønsted acid site (BAS) from nitrate ions and is very beneficial to improve the selectivity of piperidine in theory. The pore properties of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts were characterized by nitrogen adsorption-desorption method. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms (Fig. S3) and pore size distributions (Fig. 1c) of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts were obtained. The details of the pore structure of these catalysts are listed in Table 1. As shown in Fig. S3, all the synthesized samples present typical IV isotherms accompanied by capillary condensation occurring at relative pressure range of approximately 0.4–1, suggesting that the samples are rich in mesoporous structure [32]. As depicted in Fig. 1c and Table 1, the synthesized catalysts exhibited a relatively narrow distribution of pore sizes, falling within the range of 1.5–7 nm. As the TiO2 content increases, there was a continuous decline in the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter of the catalysts. In the context of pyridine molecule diffusion within the catalyst channels, the incorporation of Ti appears to be detrimental. Conversely, from the perspective of the reducibility of active metal, Ti modification significantly increased the reduction difficulty of Pt species. As clearly demonstrated by the H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) profiles in Fig. 1d, the incorporation of Ti atoms increased the reduction temperature of the active metal, and with the increase in the amount of Ti introduced, the reduction temperature of the catalysts showed a gradual upward trend. Significantly, this trend of variation in reduction temperature was observed for both the high-temperature and low-temperature reduction peaks, where the former corresponds to the reduction of tetravalent platinum, while the latter corresponds to the reduction of bivalent platinum [33]. This phenomenon could be attributed to the modification of the support electronic structure upon Ti incorporation, which alters the electron transfer dynamics between the support and Pt. Specifically, the introduction of Ti increases the chemical bond energy between Pt and the support, thereby strengthening their interaction[34]. Such a scenario cannot be ruled out: under high-temperature reduction conditions, TiO2 species might migrate to the surface of Pt particles and form partial coatings, thereby hindering Pt reduction and causing the reduction peak to shift to higher temperatures [35]. To further explore the influence of Ti introduction on the reduction characteristics of active metals, density functional theory (DFT) was used to calculate the adsorption properties of oxidic active metal on the surface of Al2O3 support before and after Ti introduction. Table 2 shows the DFT calculation results of Ti incorporation on the interaction between PtO2 and Al2O3 support. The DFT calculation results show that the binding energy of PtO2 on the pure Al2O3 surface is −204.6 kJ·mol−1, on the pure TiO2 surface is −254.9 kJ·mol−1, and on the Ti-doped Al2O3 surface is −342.9 kJ·mol−1, indicating that the interaction between PtO2 and the support increases in the order of Al2O3 < TiO2 < Ti-doped Al2O3. Firstly, from the perspective of electronegativity, Ti (electronegativity ∼1.38) and Al (electronegativity ∼1.71) exhibit distinct electron-donating capabilities compared to O (3.44). On pure Al2O3, Al3+ forms ionic bonds with O2-, creating a relatively rigid lattice that limits electron delocalization with PtO2. In contrast, TiO2 features Ti4+ with a stronger d-orbital interaction with O, enabling partial covalent character in Ti-O bonds [36]. This enhances electron transfer to PtO2, increasing binding energy. When Ti is doped into Al2O3, it not only introduces lattice distortion due to the difference in ionic radius between Ti4+ (0.605 Å) and Al3+ (0.535 Å), but also generates oxygen vacancies and electron-rich sites. These oxygen vacancies play a crucial role in strengthening the interaction with PtO2. Additionally, the reduction of Ti4+ to Ti3+ can occur under certain conditions, and the TiO2 surface oxygen vacancies or Ti3+ sites possess stronger electron-donor abilities [37]. They can donate electrons to Pt, leading to stronger orbital hybridization between Pt and the support. The unpaired electrons in Ti3+ can form covalent-like interactions with the d-orbitals of Pt, which significantly improves the binding energy of PtO2 on the support. The electronegativity gradient between Ti and Al also modifies the local electron density around O, promoting stronger Pt-O-Ti/Al bond formation. Specifically, the lower electronegativity of Ti compared to Al facilitates electron donation to PtO2, while oxygen vacancies act as Lewis basic sites to anchor Pt species. This synergistic effect strengthens orbital hybridization between Pt 5d and O 2p states, as validated by the increased binding energy. The result aligns with H2-TPR shifts, where stronger metal-support interactions (due to enhanced electron delocalization and orbital hybridization) require higher reduction temperatures. The covalent states of Pt and Ti species of the catalysts were identified and the recorded XPS spectra for Pt and Ti species are displayed in Figs. 2 and 3, respectively. The peaks at binding energies of approximately 71.8 eV (4 f7/2) and 75.7 eV (4 f5/2) corresponding to platinum in the zero-valent state, and the peaks at binding energies of about 72.7 eV (Pt2+, 4 f7/2), 76.5 eV (Pt2+, 4 f5/2),74.7 eV (Pt4+, 4 f7/2) and 78.3 eV (Pt4+, 4 f5/2) are attributed to incompletely reduced platinum species [38], as shown in Fig. S5. In the case of Ti 2p, the peaks at binding energies of about 455.8 and 462.4 eV are assigned to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 levels for trivalent Ti (Ti3+), and the peaks at approximately 458.6 and 464.7 eV are attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 levels for tetravalent Ti (Ti4+)[39,40], as shown in Fig. S6. The deconvolution results of Pt 4 f and Ti 2p derived from Fig. S5 and Fig. S6 are listed in Table 3. As presented in the data, the proportion of zero-valent Pt (Pt0) raised significantly from 48.3 % to 78.8 % with the increase of Ti content. Concurrently, the proportion of trivalent Ti (Ti3+) also showed a continuous increase. These trends suggest a strong correlation between the presence of Ti3+ species and the enhanced formation of Pt0 on the catalyst surface. The increase in the proportion of Pt0 with the rise of Ti3+ content can be rationalized from the perspective of the electronic interaction between Ti and Pt species. Since Ti3+ has an electronic configuration that allows it to act as an electron donor, the Ti3+ in the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst system can facilitate the reduction of higher-valent Pt species (such as Pt2+ or Pt4+) to Pt0 [41,42]. As more Ti3+ is present in the catalyst with increasing Ti content, more electrons are available for donation, leading to a higher degree of reduction of Pt species to the zero-valent state, thus increasing the proportion of Pt0, which is crucial for understanding the role of Ti in modifying Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. This finding seemingly contradicts the results from H2-TPR and DFT calculations, yet can be reconciled through multiple perspectives. From the electron transfer mechanism, Ti3+, with its incomplete d-orbital configuration, acts as a potent electron donor. It directly transfers electrons to Pt species, facilitating the reduction of PtO2 to Pt0, which explains the increased Pt0 ratio observed by XPS [43]. In contrast, DFT-calculated binding energies reflect the static stability of PtO2 on the support. Ti doping strengthens orbital hybridization (e.g., Pt 5d-O 2p-Ti 3d), elevating the binding energy. During H2-TPR characterization, this enhanced interaction increases the kinetic barriers for H2 adsorption and PtO2 reduction, manifested as a shift of reduction peaks to higher temperatures, indicating the kinetic nature of H2-TPR measurements. Oxygen vacancies introduced by Ti doping also play a crucial role. These vacancies capture lattice oxygen from PtO2 during reduction, forming Ti4+-oxygen vacancy-Pt0 species, thus providing an alternative pathway for PtO2 reduction and lowering the energy barrier. Although the strong Pt-O-Ti bonds require higher temperatures for direct H2-induced reduction (corresponding to the high-temperature peaks in H2-TPR), the synergistic effect of oxygen vacancies and Ti3+ promotes Pt reduction (aligned with the high Pt0 proportion in XPS). In essence, XPS probes the thermodynamic equilibrium state post-reduction, while H2-TPR captures the kinetic process of reduction. Ti3+ and oxygen vacancies harmonize these seemingly contradictory results via electron transfer and defect-mediated mechanisms. The acid properties of the catalysts were characterized by pyridine adsorbed Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR). The Py-FTIR spectra at different desorption temperature of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 2. The adsorption bands at approximately 1448, 1577, 1592 and 1613 cm−1 indicate the presence of coordinately bonded pyridine on Lewis acid site (LAS), and the bands at about 1541 and 1651 cm−1 are attributed to pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid site (BAS), while the band at approximately 1491 cm−1 can be ascribed to the pyridine combined with both LAS and BAS [44,45]. Throughout the two desorption temperatures, the series of catalysts exhibit no absorption bands associated with pyridine adsorbed on BAS. This indicates the near absence of Brønsted acid sites on the catalysts. This characteristic is crucial as it helps prevent the cleavage of the pyridine C-N bond, maintaining the integrity of pyridine molecules during relevant adsorption or catalytic processes. The acid densities of the catalysts at various desorption temperatures were quantified, and the results are presented in Table 4. Evidently, the in-situ synthesis method of incorporating Ti species into the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst led to an increase in the density of weak LAS and a concurrent decrease in the density of strong LAS. As the Ti content in the catalyst increased, this trend became more pronounced: the density of weak LAS continued to rise, whereas the density of strong LAS further declined. This phenomenon can be attributed to the substitution of coordination-unsaturated Al species on the catalyst surface by Ti atoms. The electronegativity of a Ti atom (∼1.38) is lower than that of an Al atom (∼1.71). As a result, Ti+ ion centers exhibited a weaker electron-attracting ability. This reduction in electron-attracting power was reflected in the catalyst’s acid-site characteristics, specifically, a decrease in the density of strong LAS and an increase in the density of weak LAS[46]. In order to investigate the diffusion properties of the catalysts before and after Ti incorporation, the diffusion and adsorption performances of pyridine on Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 at 25 °C were characterized by Intelligent Gravimetric Analyzer (IGA). As shown in Fig. 3a, the adsorption of pyridine on the catalyst can be categorized into three stages. In the range of relative pressure from 0 to 0.05, pyridine rapidly occupied the vacant adsorption sites on the catalyst surface. When the relative pressure is between 0.05 and 0.5, pyridine interacted strongly with the catalyst. Once the relative pressure exceeds 0.5, pyridine was adsorbed on the catalyst in both monolayer and multilayer forms. By comparing the adsorption behavior of the catalyst before and after Ti modification, it becomes clear that Ti modification can enhance the catalyst adsorption capacity for pyridine. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 3b, which presents the diffusion rate results of pyridine in Pt/Al2O3 and Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalysts, with diffusion rates of 0.02568 and 0.02719 respectively, Ti modification also enhanced the diffusion rate of pyridine molecules within the catalysts. When considering the pore properties and acid properties of the catalyst before and after Ti introduction, it is discovered that although the Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst has a lower specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore diameter, its acid density is significantly higher. As a result, it exhibited a higher diffusion rate, which demonstrates that the acid properties of the catalyst play a dominant role in the diffusion and adsorption of reactant molecules. To comprehensively understand the dispersion state of each element and the structural characteristics of the active metal Pt within the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts, high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and CO pulse chemisorption techniques were employed. Fig. 4 showcases the HAADF-STEM images along with the corresponding energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) mapping of the Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst, and the detailed structural characteristic information of the active metal is presented in Table 5. The TEM images show the lattice fringes attributed to Pt(111), and the HAADF-STEM EDS mapping images demonstrate that the Al, Ti, and Pt elements were uniformly distributed throughout the catalysts[47]. This indicates that the one-pot synthesis method utilized is highly effective in achieving high-level dispersion of different elements. Meanwhile, the well-dispersed and intact Pt nanoparticles indicates that Pt exists as supported particles rather than being alloyed or directly bonded with Ti. From the structural data of the active metals in Table 5, it is evident that the introduction of Ti led to an increase in the particle size of the active metal Pt, accompanied by a reduction in the specific surface area and dispersion of the active metal. Moreover, as the Ti content increased, the Pt particle size continued to grow, while the specific surface area and dispersion further declined. Combined with the Py-FTIR characterization results, it can be clearly found that the variation trend of Pt particle size is exactly opposite to that of strong LAS. This indicates that a decrease in the density of strong LAS on the catalyst surface is unfavorable to the dispersion of active metals. The observed increase in Pt particle size and corresponding decrease in specific surface area and dispersion with higher Ti loading are detrimental to pyridine hydrogenation performance. This phenomenon can be comprehensively elucidated by examining the microstructural and chemical interactions within the catalyst system. Firstly, the introduction of Ti disrupts the support native lattice structure due to significant differences in ionic radius and coordination environment compared to the host elements. For example, when incorporated into an Al2O3 support, the larger Ti4+ ions (ionic radius: 0.605 Å) substitute for Al3+ (0.535 Å), inducing lattice strain and surface defects. These structural perturbations alter the surface energy profile, creating energetically favorable sites that drive Pt particle migration [48]. To minimize the overall surface energy, Pt species tend to aggregate, leading to particle growth and decreased dispersion. At the atomic scale, Ti mediates the Pt-support interaction through the formation of interfacial Pt-O-Ti bonds. While these bonds initially enhance metal-support adhesion, excessive Ti incorporation leads to over-bridging of Pt particles. As the concentration of Ti increases, the interconnected Pt-O-Ti network effectively “draws” neighboring Pt species together, facilitating sintering and coarsening. Additionally, Ti doping modifies the electronic properties of the support surface. As a transition metal with variable oxidation states, Ti can act as an electron donor or acceptor, altering the charge density around Pt particles. Furthermore, the presence of Ti-induced oxygen vacancies plays a critical role. These defects act as preferential nucleation sites for Pt aggregation, accelerating particle growth kinetics. Collectively, these microstructural and electronic modifications induced by Ti doping ultimately result in a less favorable catalyst morphology for pyridine hydrogenation, characterized by reduced accessible active sites and compromised mass transfer efficiency. 3.2 Catalytic performance of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 catalysts The characterization results of the aforementioned catalysts clearly demonstrate that the introduction of Ti significantly modified the physical and chemical properties of the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. It also exhibited diverse effects on the electronic properties and structure of the active metals, and this effect varied considerably with the change in TiO2 content. To clarify the structure-activity correlation mechanism of Ti-modified catalysts, the selective hydrogenation performance of pyridine was evaluated in a fixed-bed hydrogenation reactor. The pyridine conversion and piperidine selectivity were determined at a reaction pressure of 4 MPa, a H2/oil (v/v) ratio of 300, a liquid hourly space velocity (LHSV) of 6 h−1, and reaction temperatures ranging from 120 to 200 °C, as depicted in Fig. 5. The pyridine conversion of the series of catalysts increased with the rise in reaction temperature. This is primarily because the increase in reaction temperature enhances the kinetic energy of pyridine molecules and hydrogen, thereby promoting the activation of reactant molecules. At all the investigated reaction temperatures, the pyridine conversions of different catalysts follow a similar order: Pt/Ti0/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti2.5/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti5/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti10/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3. The Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst, containing 7.5 wt% TiO2, showed the highest pyridine conversion (87.8 %), which is 7.5 % higher than that of the Pt/Ti0/Al2O3 catalyst without TiO2 at the reaction temperature of 160 °C. Regarding the selectivity of the target product, piperidine, it was not linearly related to the change in temperature. As the reaction temperature increased, the selectivity of all catalysts to piperidine first raised and then fell, reaching a maximum at 160 °C. Consistent with the change in pyridine conversion, the selectivity of each catalyst to piperidine at different temperatures also followed the trend of Pt/Ti0/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti2.5/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti5/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti10/Al2O3 < Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3. The Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst exhibited the highest piperidine selectivity (92.4 %), which is 9.9 % higher than that of the Pt/Ti0/Al2O3 catalyst at the reaction temperature of 160 °C. To evaluate the long-term performance of the catalyst under actual reaction conditions, a 100-h stability test was conducted on the optimal-performing Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst under the following reaction conditions: pressure of 4 MPa, H2/oil (v/v) ratio of 300, LHSV of 6 h−1, and reaction temperature of 160 °C. The results show that both the pyridine conversion and piperidine selectivity maintained good stability during the 100-h continuous operation (Fig. S7), with the both declines being less than 1.5 %, indicating that no significant agglomeration of active components or coking occurred in the catalyst during long-term operation. To investigate the impact of Ti incorporation on the selective hydrogenation pathway of pyridine, the product distributions and intermediate selectivities were analyzed via a GC-MS method at comparable pyridine conversions of 80 ± 0.5 %. Scheme 1 presents the proposed pyridine hydrogenation reaction network over the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 series catalysts[49,50]. Table 6 shows the pyridine hydrogenation product distributions at a reaction temperature of 160 °C. Based on the reaction product distribution, it can be observed that the by-products of pyridine hydrogenation were predominantly polymerization products in this reaction system, including monocyclic polymerization products 1-butylpiperidine and 1-pentylpiperidine, as well as bicyclic polymerization products 1, 5-bis(piperidin-1-yl)pentane. In contrast, there were scarcely any hydrogenolysis products of piperidine, such as amylamine and butylamine. This indicates that under these conditions, the ring-opening products formed by the cleavage of the C-N bond in piperidine and the products further cleaved by the C-C bond readily polymerize with piperidine. Once new ring-opening products were generated, they reacted with piperidine instantaneously, leading to an almost zero selectivity for ring-opening products. From the reaction rate constant and piperidine product selectivity results presented in Table 6, it is evident that during the continuous selective hydrogenation of pyridine to piperidine, the performance of the Pt/Tix/Al2O3 series catalysts initially improved and then deteriorated as the TiO2 content increased. The optimal performance was attained when the TiO2 content is 7.5 wt%. In the pyridine hydrogenation process, the electronic properties and geometric structure of the active metal in the catalyst play a decisive role. These characteristics of the active metal are closely associated with the TiO2 content in the catalyst. As the TiO2 content in the catalyst rose, the reduction degree of the active metal increased, while the specific surface area and dispersion of the active metal declined. The reduction degree of active metals indicates the proportion of actually active metal, and an increase in this index is theoretically conducive to enhancing the catalyst activity. The specific surface area and dispersion of the active metal reflect the utilization ratio of active metal atoms, and a decrease in this index will theoretically have adverse impacts on the catalyst activity. When the TiO2 content in the catalyst is 7.5 wt%, a balance was struck among the reduction degree, specific surface area, and dispersion of the active metal. Consequently, the catalyst exhibited the best activity and selectivity. Notably, the selectivity of the by-product 1, 5-bis(piperidin-1-yl)pentane decreased with the increasing TiO2 content. This might be attributed to the pore properties of the catalyst. As the TiO2 content increased, the pore volume and average pore diameter of the catalyst decreased. Given the large spatial size of 1, 5-bis(piperidin-1-yl)pentane, the catalyst exerted a shape-selective catalytic effect on it. Insufficiently large pore properties were unable to support the formation of 1, 5-bis(piperidin-1-yl)pentane, thus leading to a decrease in its selectivity [51]. To some extent, this also inhibited the further transformation of piperidine. 4 Conclusion A series of Ti-modified Pt-supported Al2O3 catalysts were successfully synthesized via a one-pot hydrothermal method. The influence of Ti incorporation on the physicochemical properties of Pt/Al2O3 was systematically investigated, and the catalytic performance of these catalysts in the selective continuous hydrogenation of pyridine was evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor. The results revealed that Ti modification reduced the density of strong Lewis acid sites on the catalysts, thus resulting in a decrease in Pt dispersion. Conversely, the introduction of Ti atoms significantly enhanced the reducibility of Pt species, which could be attributed to the formation of Ti³ ⁺ species. Reaction data indicated that the catalyst with a TiO2 content of 7.5 wt% exhibited the highest hydrogenation activity and selectivity. Under the conditions of 160 °C, 4.0 MPa, a H2/oil ratio of 300 (v/v), and a LHSV of 6 h−1 in the fixed-bed continuous hydrogenation process, this catalyst achieved a pyridine conversion of 87.8 % and a piperidine selectivity of 92.4 %. This optimal performance was attributed to the balanced state of the active metal dispersion and reducibility at this specific Ti loading, where the synergy between these two factors maximized the active metal utilization ratio, thus leading to the catalyst being able to maximize its catalytic efficiency. coredata.dc:description: Pyridine selective hydrogenation to piperidine is an important alternative to chemical synthesis. The commercial pyridine hydrogenation technologies taking Pt/Pd/Rh supported on carbon material as catalysts suffer from difficult molding and poor mechanical properties, resulting in their inability to be applied to continuous catalytic hydrogenation process. Here, Ti modified Pt-supported Al2O3 catalyst used in continuous hydrogenation process was synthesized via a one-pot hydrothermal method. Using a variety of complementary characterization methods, we identified the existence forms of Pt and Ti species in the catalyst. The results revealed that Ti modification decreased the density of strong Lewis acid sites on the catalysts, resulting in a decrease in Pt dispersion. Conversely, the introduction of Ti atoms significantly enhanced the reducibility of Pt species. This can be attributed to the formation of Ti3 + species, whose presence effectively facilitated the reduction of higher-valent Pt species (Pt2+ and Pt4+) to Pt0. The Pt/Ti7.5/Al2O3 catalyst with 7.5 wt% TiO2-containing achieved up to 87.8 % conversion of pyridine and 92.4 % selectivity of target product piperidine at 160 °C, 4.0 MPa, 300 H2/oil (v/v), and 6 h−1 LHSV in the fixed-bed continuous hydrogenation process, an improvement of 7.5 % and 9.9 % respectively, compared to Pt/Al2O3 catalyst. This optimal performance can be attributed to the balanced state of the active metal dispersion and reducibility at this specific Ti loading, where the synergy between these two factors maximized the active metal utilization ratio, thus leading to the catalyst being able to maximize its catalytic efficiency.
